importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, indicating the most recent update in the current postseason series. The Mariners are within one win of their first World Series appearance, making this date pivotal in the context of franchise history.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The 1995 and 2001 seasons mark key moments in Mariners history: the 1995 ALDS victory, often credited with saving baseball in Seattle, and the 2001 ALCS, which was a turning point in fan engagement and team momentum.

keyTakeAways: Eugenio Suárez hit a grand slam in the bottom of the eighth inning, the second in franchise postseason history, giving the Mariners a 6-2 lead over the Toronto Blue Jays.
The Mariners now lead the series 3-2, with just one more win needed to reach their first World Series appearance in franchise history.
This achievement makes the Mariners the only active major league team never to have made it to the Fall Classic, adding historical significance to the current series.
Cal Raleigh hit a game-tying homer in the eighth inning, the first such occurrence in Seattle's postseason history since 2001, signaling a resurgence of momentum.
Suárez's performance was emotional and historic, especially in front of his family and fans, with the moment described as the most powerful swing by a Mariner in 30 years.
The Mariners’ journey reflects a long-standing desire to reach the World Series, with prior near-misses in 1995 and 2001, making this current run especially meaningful.

namedEntities.name: Eugenio Suárez
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Suárez’s grand slam in the eighth inning was the pivotal moment that shifted the Mariners’ playoff momentum and brought them within one win of their first World Series appearance, marking a historic achievement in franchise history.

namedEntities.name: Seattle Mariners
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Mariners are the only active MLB franchise never to reach the World Series, making their current position in the postseason a major milestone in the team’s history.

namedEntities.name: Toronto Blue Jays
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Blue Jays are the opposing team in the playoff series, and their previous wins in Seattle (Games 3 and 4) created a critical series situation that Suárez’s grand slam overcame.

namedEntities.name: Cal Raleigh
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Raleigh’s game-tying home run in the eighth inning was a critical moment in the game and the first such occurrence in Mariners postseason history since 2001, highlighting a resurgence of team momentum.

namedEntities.name: Bryce Miller
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Miller was the Mariners’ starter who was removed in the fifth inning, leading to a series of scoring opportunities that ultimately contributed to the game’s outcome.

namedEntities.name: George Springer
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Springer hit a two-out double in the fifth inning that drove in Addison Barger, tying the game and contributing to the Mariners' comeback momentum.

namedEntities.name: Ernie Clement
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Clement’s single in the sixth inning drove in Alejando Kirk, extending the Mariners’ lead and helping to secure the victory.

namedEntities.name: Addison Barger
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Barger was driven in by George Springer’s double in the fifth inning, contributing to the Mariners' ability to tie the game during the series.

namedEntities.name: Alejando Kirk
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Kirk was driven in by Ernie Clement’s single in the sixth inning, adding to the Mariners’ scoring in a pivotal stretch of the game.

namedEntities.name: Dan Wilson
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: As the team’s manager, Wilson expressed emotional reactions to the game’s climax, describing the crowd noise and historical significance of Suárez’s hit.

namedEntities.name: 2001 American League Championship Series
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The 2001 ALCS is referenced as a turning point in Mariners history, where a game-tying homer by Bret Boone marked a pivotal moment, and the absence of such a moment in 24 years underscores the emotional significance of Raleigh’s homer.

namedEntities.name: 1995 American League Division Series
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Mariners’ 1995 ALDS win is seen as a key moment that saved baseball in Seattle, establishing a legacy of resilience and fan connection.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Eugenio Suárez's grand slam in the bottom of the eighth inning gave the Seattle Mariners a 6-2 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays, propelling them to a 3-2 series lead and within one win of their first World Series appearance. This moment marks the second grand slam in Mariners postseason history and is described as the most important swing by a Mariner in 30 years. The Mariners, who have never reached the World Series, now face just one more win to break their long-standing streak, making this achievement historically significant. Cal Raleigh's game-tying homer in the eighth inning also marks a historic moment, being the first such event in the franchise's postseason since 2001. The article highlights emotional reactions from players and fans, referencing past near-misses in 1995 and 2001, and the deep cultural significance of baseball in Seattle.
title: Eugenio Suárez grand slam powers Seattle Mariners to within one win of first World Series
